items.abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
            <jats:p>We say that a first order formula Φ <jats:italic>distinguishes</jats:italic> a structure <jats:italic>M</jats:italic> over a vocabulary <jats:italic>L</jats:italic> from another structure <jats:italic>M</jats:italic>′ over the same vocabulary if Φ is true on <jats:italic>M</jats:italic> but false on <jats:italic>M</jats:italic>′. A formula Φ <jats:italic>defines</jats:italic> an <jats:italic>L</jats:italic>-structure <jats:italic>M</jats:italic> if Φ distinguishes <jats:italic>M</jats:italic> from any other non-isomorphic <jats:italic>L</jats:italic>-structure <jats:italic>M</jats:italic>′. A formula Φ <jats:italic>identifies</jats:italic> an <jats:italic>n</jats:italic>-element <jats:italic>L</jats:italic>-structure <jats:italic>M</jats:italic> if Φ distinguishes <jats:italic>M</jats:italic> from any other non-isomorphic <jats:italic>n</jats:italic>-element <jats:italic>L</jats:italic>-structure <jats:italic>M</jats:italic>′.</jats:p>
            <jats:p>We prove that every <jats:italic>n</jats:italic>-element structure <jats:italic>M</jats:italic> is identifiable by a formula with quantifier rank less than <jats:inline-graphic xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" mime-subtype="gif" xlink:href="S0022481200007003_inline1" xlink:type="simple" /> and at most one quantifier alternation, where <jats:italic>k</jats:italic> is the maximum relation arity of M. Moreover, if the automorphism group of <jats:italic>M</jats:italic> contains no transposition of two elements, the same result holds for definability rather than identification.</jats:p>
            <jats:p>The Bernays-Schönfinkel class consists of prenex formulas in which the existential quantifiers all precede the universal quantifiers. We prove that every <jats:italic>n</jats:italic>-element structure <jats:italic>M</jats:italic> is identifiable by a formula in the Bernays-Schönfinkel class with less than <jats:inline-graphic xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" mime-subtype="gif" xlink:href="S0022481200007003_inline2" xlink:type="simple" /> quantifiers. If in this class of identifying formulas we restrict the number of universal quantifiers to <jats:italic>k</jats:italic>, then less than <jats:inline-graphic xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" mime-subtype="gif" xlink:href="S0022481200007003_inline3" xlink:type="simple" /> quantifiers suffice to identify <jats:italic>M</jats:italic> and. as long as we keep the number of universal quantifiers bounded by a constant, at total <jats:inline-graphic xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" mime-subtype="gif" xlink:href="S0022481200007003_inline4" xlink:type="simple" />quantifiers are necessary.</jats:p>
title: Descriptive complexity of finite structures: Saving the quantifier rank

items.abstract: <jats:p>This work is devoted to theoretical and experimental study of energy dissipation and storage processes in titanium alloys under quasistatic loading. The specimen surface temperature was measured by infrared camera FLIR SC 5000 (a spectral range of 3-5 micron). Extending previous results of the research group in Perm, we coupled the experimental investigation of temperature evolution with a statistical description of the mesodefect ensemble. It allowed us to propose a thermodynamic internal variable model of heat dissipation in metals.</jats:p>
title: Experimental Study of Defect Induced Temperature Evolution in Polycrystalline Metals
